Award.AwardTitle: Building Community and Transforming Practice with Faculty Triads

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The significance of this project is to improve foundational, large-enrollment classes at Rochester Institute of Technology (RIT) that contribute to developing a technologically proficient workforce. Faculty from departments of chemistry, biology, physics and mathematics will be brought together in small teams ("triads") to develop student-centered approaches that result in improved learning and performance. Targeted courses have historically struggled particularly with retention of underrepresented groups; emphasizing deeper understanding and non-lecture-based teaching methods addresses retention of this important population. The project also carefully assesses student learning, using the results to inform class processes and connect learning to broader objectives of career preparation. Finally, by explicitly studying how innovations disseminate throughout the four departments, the project increases the likelihood of widespread adoption, impacting faculty across RIT's College of Science.

The project's goal is to disseminate and institutionalize research-based pedagogies across multi-section courses through the work of four faculty triads --- collaborative teams of three faculty working together to transform high-enrollment, introductory STEM courses, which will affect approximately 1500 students. Two courses with historically large attrition --- Introductory Calculus-based Physics and Elements in Multivariable Calculus & Differential Equations --- will be initially targeted, and the work in these courses will serve as models for future triads. Mechanisms to incorporate course transformation and assessment activities into faculty plans of work and annual reviews will be developed, thus ensuring institutional recognition and support for the work of the faculty. Close analysis of the triads will contribute to greater understanding of institutional change, including important issues about the balance between emergent and prescribed projects and which team tasks best promote change. The project, particularly the work within the triads, also encourages the development of specific learning goals and assessment measures. Collaboration with an existing Discipline-Based Education Research (DBER) team enables triad faculty groups to incorporate research-based materials and assessments into their work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This porject created institutional transformation through faculty triads, groups of three faculty that collectively are responsible for large, multi-section (often introductory) STEM courses. Triads are a version of a faculty learning community, with the added benefit of an immediate, practical goal of course transformation. The integration of support before and during the course allowed faculty to engage meaningfully with the relevant discipline-based education research, identifying philosophies and strategies to bring to bear in their respective courses. Most critically, the experience built relationships and fostered meaningful discussions that persisted beyond the specific classes, showing the potential for nucleating faculty culture change in small clusters of connected faculty. Faculty were recruited and supported in their use of a backwards design approach to transform their respective foundational introductory STEM courses. We found strong evidence that the Triad framework created groups that functioned as strong faculty learning communities, building sense of community through collaboration while fostering pedagogical change and personal growth.

Over the 4 year period of the grant four Facutly Triads (teams of 3 faculty each) were funded to transform physics, biology and math classrooms. Triads for physics and math transformed the Calculus-based Introductory physics I class, including a separate section for students arriving with less math preparation, and the "Introduction to Multivariable Calculus and Differential Equations" math class that targets Engineering Technology majors. Both have been shown to present obstacles for studetns to progressing through the program. Two biology Triads  addressed "Introduction to Biology" (including labs) and "Cellular and Molecular Biology," a course that foucses on majors. Triads thoroughly revised course syllabi, goals and objectives to transform the class to include more active-inquiry pedagogies. All Triads met weekly throughout the summer, developing relationships and trust that were critical to their persistence throughout the course revision process.

There were three key project objectives: to transform classrooms, to develop trust and relationships between faculty, and to conduct new education research on institutional change. Each of these is addressed in turn.

1. Classroom Transformation. Each Triad was responsible for transforming multiple-sections of a large, introductory classroom to incorporate techniques and pedagogies known to facilitate studnet learning. Each Triad had agency to determine their own learning goals, objectives and strategies for achieving them. Thus, each had a different "flavor" of transformation. The Elements of Multivariable Calculus and Differential Equations" focused on Interactive Lecture Demonstrations that students could interact with. The Calculus-based physics Triad focused on incorporating complex problems that directly discussed different levels of understanding according to Bloom's Taxonomy. Biology Triads learned from the earlier Triads, incorporating elements of both.

2. Faculty relationships. A key objective was to give faculty extended time and space to engage in higher-order discussions about teaching, going beyond simply what was planned for that week's class, developing lasting bonds that would persiste beyond the grant period. This appears to have succeeded for three of the four Triads, with Math the lone exception. Our research indicates that faculty saw great benefit in the relationships they developed with peers and that these bonds became particularly instrumental during the Spring of 2020 when the COVID-19 pandemic necessitated rapid, drastic changes in pedagogies. Faculty report seeing the Triad as providing support for other classrooms, as they are often the first people they turn to when questions arise. The failure of the Math Triad appears to have been a combination of three factors: individual personalities of Triad members that proved incompatible, a leadership style of a Triad member that was more directive and less consensus-driven, and a particularly hands-off approach of department administration that gave little reward for maintaining the activities.

3. Education Research on Institutional Transformation. The final year of the project was spent conducting interviews of Triad faculty participants and Department and College Administration. This revealed both the beneficial nature of Triad activities to faculty relationships and also an ambivalent approach of Department and College Leadership. In particular, Department Heads recognized the value of Triad discussions and activities but were very hesitant to do anything that would appear to elevate the groups above other faculty, or to require tasks (such as articulating learning goals) that Triad participants recognized as valuable but also noted they would not have done had they not been required to by the Triad project.

In conclusion, the Triad project presents a new model for faculty learning communities, bringing together faculty from a single departement with a common goal of transforming classrooms. When given time and space to consider course goals and objectives and critical guiding quesitons to promote higher-order thinking, faculty are remarkably creative in their designs and form robust, successful teams.
